In this study, density functional theory calculations and microkinetic modeling were used to estimate the catalytic activity of ReδCo1-δ(0001) alloys (δ = 0; 0.25; 0.5; 0.75, 1), and Co(0001)-supported single- Re1 and dual-atom Re2 centers in the synthesis of ammonia. Nitrogen atoms (Nad) form an ordered structure, and the bridge state is most active among others on the Re(0001) plane; while Nad are concentrated around the Re1 and Re2 centers, splitting in electronic and thermodynamic properties. The specific catalytic activity of the centers Re1, Re2 and the Re(0001) plane changes in the order of 8.0·103, 32.0, and 1.0, respectively, due to weakly bound but highly active Nad, which are stabilized by strongly bound and low-active Nad. The calculations revealed the NRe3 state on the Re3Co1 alloy with an abnormally high binding energy (BE) of -7.05 eV, unequal Re-N distances and Re5d fillings, in contrast to the similar NRe3 state on Re(0001) with BE = -6.71 eV. A variable synergism of Re-Co alloys was established: the Re3Co1 or Re1Co3 alloy exhibits maximum catalytic activity if the rate-determining step is the formation or hydrogenation of Nad under appropriate experimental conditions, respectively. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Active site modeling Ammonia synthesis Re-Co alloy Single-atom catalyst 1 Introduction The Haber-Bosch process has remained important for the theory and practice of heterogeneous catalysis for more than a century. It is still a touchstone for fundamental research in such fields as the concepts of active centers and electron donation [1,2], the d-band model, and the relationship between the electronic, thermodynamic, and catalytic properties of the catalyst [3–8]. The synthesis of ammonia is highly sensitive to the surface structure; for example, the specific turnover frequency (TOF) increases by ∼103 and ∼400 times in the rows of the crystal faces Re(0001), Re ( 10 1 ¯ 0 ) , Re ( 11 2 ¯ 0 ) , Re ( 11 2 ¯ 1 ) and Fe(110), Fe(100), Fe(211), Fe(111), respectively [9–11]. On an industrial scale, ammonia is produced mainly on doubly promoted iron catalysts (Fe-K2O-Al2O3) and partly on more expensive but highly active Ru-based catalysts; in particular, a carbon-supported Ru catalyst exhibits ten times higher activity than Fe-Al2O3-K2O [12–14]. It is believed that the high activity of Fe and Ru is determined by the specific catalytic center Fe-C7 and Ru-B5, respectively. Among other tested systems, mixed Mo-Co nitrides showed a sufficiently good activity-cost ratio to compete with existing industrial catalysts [12,15]. The steady growth of ammonia consumption stimulates fundamental and applied research, as well as the search for new catalysts and methods with the use and development of the scientific basis in this field [16,17]. Rhenium also deserves attention as a catalyst for NH3 synthesis due to its excellent catalytic activity in this process. It was found that the activity of Re foil is almost an order of magnitude higher than that of the most active Fe(111) single crystal [18], and it was suggested that a low and high coverage of N atoms (Nad) leads, respectively, to a roughening and smoothing of the polycrystalline foil [19]. It was also shown that the specific turnover frequency (TOF) of supported Re is ∼10 and ∼7 times higher than the TOF of supported Ru and Fe-Al2O3-K2O, respectively [14,20]. It should be noted that Re is characterized by a high atomization enthalpy ΔfH0 = 7.98 eV compared to ΔfH0 = 6.66 eV for Ru and 4.31 eV for Fe [21]. In addition, Re demonstrates a high Nad binding energy BE(N) from -6.5 eV to -6.9 eV [20,22–24] compared to BE(N) for Ru from -5.1 to -5.7 eV [25–27], BE(N) for Fe from -5.6 to -6.2 eV [27–29], and BE(N) = -6.0 eV for Fe/Al2O3 [30]. The high enthalpy ΔfH0 promotes the formation of close-packed structures and hinders the formation of low-coordinate centers, such as the highly active Ru-B5. In turn, the strong Re-N bond reduces the affinity of Nad for hydrogenation. Cobalt exhibits low activity in the dissociative adsorption of N2, as well as in the synthesis of ammonia, which, however, increases by ∼100 times in the presence of Ba and Ce promoters [31–34]. The TOF of metal catalysts in the synthesis of NH3 obeys a volcano dependence on the heat of dissociative adsorption of N2 (QN ), demonstrating the Sabatier principle: the N-M bond must be strong, but not too strong for the efficient formation and hydrogenation of adsorbed nitrogen atoms (Nad), which corresponds to the left and right sides of the volcano curve, respectively [35,36]. The most important QN are around the maximum TOF, which indicates a change in the rate-determining step (RDS) from the formation of Nad to their consumption and a change in the Nad coverage from low to significant. The combination of metals with high and low QN turned out to be a fruitful strategy for the formation of active centers [37–40]. In this regard, Re-Co alloys are of particular interest due to their synergetic catalytic behavior [41–45]. It was assumed that their activity is due to the formation of a bimetallic phase, but the nature of their highly active centers remains unclear [41,43]. The electronic configuration of the transition state of the RDS is eventually responsible for the activity of a catalytic center [2,4]. With regard to ammonia synthesis, it is due to the σ-donation and π* back-donation between a transition metal and N2 molecule that occur under activating the NN triple bond [8,46–48]. A drastic increase in the activity of Ru-based catalysts depending on an electron-donating ability of the support and promoter components was demonstrated [3]. The high catalytic performance of Ru nanoparticles supported on a powder of BaO and CaH2 was particularly enabled by enhanced electron donation from BaH2 to Ru [5]. The intermetallic compounds of Ru and more electropositive metals, such as YRu2, were more efficient catalysts than pure Ru because of the large electron promotion [6]. The strong electron donation to Ru metal in Ru-loaded Y5Si3 enhanced the N2 dissociation and reduced the activation energy of the ammonia synthesis [7]. The first-principles calculations have revealed that the Mo-embedded stanene exhibits excellent activity in the electro-catalytic NH3 synthesis due to an electron conductivity of Sn [8]. Thus, the transfer of electrons between the components of a complex catalyst can be an important part of its catalytic performance. The single-atom approach allows one to create a catalytic site of a desired structure and composition and ensures the optimal use of an expensive active component [49–51]. This study is aimed at identifying and using the hidden capabilities of Re in the synthesis of ammonia, taking into account the literature data. In particular, we consider catalytic centers around one or a pair of Re atoms on a Co(0001) support to achieve the following three purposes: to evaluate the effect of the electron-donating ability of a metal support on the activity of Re-based centers; to suppress the tendency of Re to form close-packed structures by reducing the number of Re-Re bonds; and to reduce the strength of the Re-N bond due to the presence of Co, which is less active than Re in Nad binding. The Co(0001) plane and the single-atom Co center on Re(0001) were also considered to complete the picture. Re-Co alloys were studied in order to determine the origin of their synergetic behavior. The TOF of the Fe(111) plane was calculated for comparison with the experimental data on single crystals of Fe and Re to justify the reliability of the calculations. 2 Theoretical Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations have been performed using the Quantum Espresso (QE) package [52] and the non-local exchange-correlation functional in the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof parameterization [53]. The interactions between ionic cores and electrons were described by the Projected Augmented Wave method with a kinetic energy cutoff 65 Ry (Co(0001) and Fe(111) systems) and 55 Ry (Re(0001)) for a plane-wave basis set [54]. The Methfessel-Paxton first-order spreading was used with a Gaussian spreading factor of 0.2 eV for the Brillouin-zone integration. The Brillouin zone was integrated on a 3 × 3 × 1 grid of Monkhorst-Pack k-points [55]. The Re(0001), Co(0001) and ReδCo1-δ(0001) planes were simulated with slabs consisting of five layers (two bottom layers were frozen) with a 2 × 2 unit cell. This corresponds to a surface coverage of 0.25 ML, with only one adsorbate per unit cell. The Fe(111) plane was modeled with the 10-layer slab (six bottom layers were frozen) with a 1 × 2 unit cell. For the calculations of single-atom centers, the following experimental lattice parameters were used: a = b = 2.5071 Å, c = 4.0695 Å for Co, a = b = 2.761 Å, c = 4.456 Å for Re, and a = 2.8665 Å for Fe [56]. For the calculations of alloys, the lattice parameters were optimized. The slabs were separated by a vacuum region of ∼15 Å. The filling of the outer shells was approximated by the charges of the corresponding states. QE gives a complete filling of the s shells, so the Co3s and Re5s orbitals were considered fully filled, and the remaining charge was attributed to the Co4s and Re6s orbitals, respectively. The product yield in the catalytic NH3 synthesis is determined by the following processes: ½ H2 + Slab ↔ H + QH Step (1) ½ N2 + Slab ↔ N + QN Step (2) N + H → NH + QN+H Step (3) Hereinafter, the adsorbed states are underlined in Italic; QH (set independent of coverage and surface structure) [57,58], QN, and QN+H are the heats of respective steps, and steps (1) and (2) are in equilibrium [59,60]. Step (3) is the RDS under the equilibrium conditions for steps (1) and (2). The total reaction rate w N H 3 , if the state N is represented by several stable states ( N i ) found from calculations, can be described within the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism as follows: w N H 3 = k 3 θ H ∑ θ N i k 3 = k 3 , 0 exp { − E 3 / R T } θ H = K H / ( 1 + K H + ∑ K N i ) , where K H = K H , 0 exp { Q H / R T } θ N i = K N i / ( 1 + K H + ∑ K N i ) , where K N i = K N , 0 exp { Q N i / R T } Here, the activation energy for the rate constant k3 follows the Brønsted-Evans-Polanyi (BEP) relation E 3 , i = E 3 , 0 − β · Q N i + H (β = 0.5 is the universal BEP coefficient, and the constant E3,0 is set to be the same for all states) [61]; θH, KH , and θ N i , K N i are equilibrium coverage and constant of step (1) and (2), respectively; K N , 0 and K H , 0 are pre-exponential factors. The turnover frequency (TOF) of the free N i state and its partial TOF (pTOFi) in a mix of states (NH3 moles per metal atom per second), and the specific TOF of the slab (NH3 moles per cm2 per second, ignoring the difference in the atomic densities) are in proportion: (1) T O F ∝ K H K N i exp { ( β · Q N i + H ) / R T } ( 1 + K H + K N i ) 2 p T O F i ∝ K H K N i exp { ( β · Q N i + H ) / R T } ( 1 + K H + ∑ K N i ) 2 Specific T O F = ∑ p T O F i The TOFs were calculated by Eq. (1) for typical conditions of the process (T ∼800 K, total pressure P ∼30 MPa, N2:H2 = 1:3) [62]), corresponding to the pre-exponential factors K N , 0 = 0.02719 and K H , 0 = 0.09111 (Table S1), sticking coefficient 1 for the N2 and H2 adsorption, unified atomic density d M = 1•1015 cm−2, and the weighted mean adsorption heat Q H = ∑ θ H , i Q H , i related to the optimized free H states (Table 1 ). Reaction orders with respect to N2 ∼0.9 and H2 ∼-0.2, which were determined for a stoichiometric N2 and H2 mixture, are consistent with the competitive adsorption of N2 and H2 in Eq. (1) [11,44,45]. The observed reverse isotope effect is also consistent with Eq. (1), which remain correct even at a non-equilibrium step (2) due to the BEP relation. The heats of steps (1-3), atomization energies (Eat) of the N2 and H2 molecules and binding energies (BE) of the Nad and Had species were determined using conventional relations: Q H = − E Slab + H + E Slab + E H + 1 / 2 E at ( H 2 ) Q N = − E Slab + N + E Slab + E N + 1 / 2 E at ( N 2 ) Q N H = − E Slab + NH + E Slab + E NH + 1 / 2 E at ( N 2 ) + 1 / 2 E at ( H 2 ) Q N + H = Q NH − Q N − Q H E at ( N 2 ; H 2 ) = E N 2 ; H 2 − 2 E N ; H BE ( N ) = E Slab + N − E Slab − E N = 1 / 2 E at ( N 2 ) − Q N BE ( H ) = E Slab + H − E Slab − E H = 1 / 2 E at ( H 2 ) − Q H Here, ESlab and ESlab+X are formation energies of the free Slab and Slab + an adsorbed species X (X = H, N, NH), respectively; EY is a formation energy of a free atom or molecule Y (Y = H; N; NH, N2, H2). All the formation energies were obtained from DFT runs. 3 Results and discussion The calculated Eat(N2) = -10.48 eV and Eat(H2) = -4.54 eV exceed the corresponding reference energies -9.76 and -4.48 eV [63], but this systematic deviation is unlikely to affect the results of this article. Indeed, the calculated weighted average QN values of 1.4168 eV and 1.0888 eV for the Re(0001) and Fe(111) planes are close to the published ranges of 1.18-1.66 eV and 1.09-1.11 eV, respectively [24,64,65]. The same applies to the values of BE(H) in Table 1. The XY views of free slabs and the atonic coordinates of most important slabs are shown in Fig. 1 S and in Tables S2-S7, respectively. 3.1 Re(0001) As expected, the calculations have revealed that the fcc and hcp states NRe3 on the plane Re (0001) make the main contribution to QN (Fig. 1) and to the coverage [71]. The TOF of a site is determined by the combination of QN and QNH (4, 5), which depends on the location of N and NH species. The N and NH species were moved between the fcc and hcp sites to find the TOF of 13 intermediate N states, including bridge states #7-#9 and three fold states #1 and #13 in Fig. 1(a). The strong maximum in Fig. 1(b) corresponds to the bridge states #7-#9, with lower QN and QNH . The N and NH paths are slightly different, so the calculated QN values were updated by adapting XY coordinates of the N species to those of the NH species (Fig. 1(c)). Thus, the optimal combination of QN and QN+H on the plane Re(0001) provides the maximum TOF of the bridge state NRe2. 3.2 Re1 and Re2 centers on Co(0001) The optimization showed that single and a pair of Re atoms (further regarded as a Re1 and Re2 center, respectively) occupy hcp sites of the plane Co(0001). The energy advantage of 3.5 eV of the center Re2 over two centers Re1, which was estimated as E(Re2/Co) + E(Co) – 2E(Re1/Co), suggests that Re atoms bind with each other, forming a graphene-like structure (Fig. 2 ). The catalytic behavior of Re-based active sites depends on the N coverage. The coverage θN = 0.25 and θN = 0.5 ML corresponds respectively to one and two atoms N per a Re1 or Re2 center. 3.2.1 Coverage 0.25 ML Free N states on Re(0001), Re1/Co(0001), and Re2/Co(0001) at θN = 0.25 ML are characterized in Fig. 3 (a) and Table 2 . The calculated adsorption heats QN conform well to data reported for the NRe3 fcc 1.33 eV and 1.46 eV [72], NRe3 hcp 1.42 eV, and NRe on-top state -0.31 eV [24]. Generally, a strongly bound semi-active state dominates in the adsorbed layer over weakly bound highly active states. As a result, the specific TOF of the plane Re(0001) and Re1 and Re2 centers changes in the order 1.0, 9.0, and 3.6•10−7, whereas the TOF of the most active N states changes as 21.1 (NRe3 hcp), 2.3·104 (NRe), and 1.3·104 (NReCo3), respectively. The N states at θN = 0.25 ML are considered as predecessors of the N states at θN = 0.5 ML. 3.2.2 Coverage 0.5 ML Stable configurations of the N species on Re(0001) and centers Re1 and Re2 on Co(0001) at θN = 0.5 ML exhibit specific geometry (Fig. 3(b)) and lateral interaction (Table 3 ). The N-N repulsion energy EN-N was estimated as follows. In the case of the Re(0001), EN-N was the difference between the total QN at θN = 0.5 ML and doubled QN at θN = 0.25 ML. In the case of Re1 and Re2 centers, EN-N was the difference between the total QN at θN = 0.5 ML and a sum of QN of similar N states at θN = 0.25 ML (Tables 2 and 3). The similarity of N states was deduced from their binding to the surface (Fig. 3). In the case of the Re1 center, the state (A1) NReNCo3 is close to a combination of states (a1) NRe and (c1) ReNCo3, while states (B1) ReNCo2 and (C1) CoNReNCo3 approximately consist of (b1) ReNCo and (c1) ReNCo3. On the Re2 center, the state (A2) NRe2 is the doubled state (c2) NRe2, while states (B2) ReNReNCo3 and (C2) NRe2NCo2 are approximately combined of (c2) NRe2 and (c1) ReNCo3. The lateral interaction and coordination environment make the N atoms, joint in a particular state, to differ in QN and QNH . The QN value, which is responsible for QN+H , results from the process: N (0.25 ML) + ½N2 → 2 N (0.5 ML) + QN . Therefore, QN of an added, always weakly bound, N atom was determined as the difference between the total QN,tot at θN = 0.5 ML and the weighted mean Q N = ∑ θ N i Q N i at θN = 0.25 ML, which corresponds to QN of a predecessor, the strongly bound N atom. In addition, the adsorption heat QN,tot , for example, of the state (A1), which determines its partial coverage, in a mixture of states (A1), (A2), and (A3), was applied to the K N i of both N atoms of the state (A1). In contrast to the free states in Table 2, the strongly bound N atom of the state (A1) actually stabilizes the weakly bound N atom, whose superior catalytic activity is mainly provided by a significant QN+H . The same applies to the other states in Table 3. The catalytic performance of the highly active N state over a surface, which is modified by the strongly bound N state, is in line with the ∼4 fold higher activity of a system Re+Re3N compared to metal Re [44]. The heats of step (3) were calculated for one QNH (I) and both QNH (II) hydrogenated N atoms. QNH (I) corresponds to the weaker bound N atom, which is always hydrogenated first, while the QNH of the stronger bound N atom was defined as the difference between QNH (II) and QNH (I). The repulsive energy NH-NH (ENH-NH) was estimated as the difference between QNH (II) and the sum of QNH of the same or similar free states (at θN = 0.25 ML). The optimized fcc and hcp NRe3 states on Re(0001) are in ordered structures (Fig. 3(b)) in agreement with the experimental data [71]. The specific TOF of Re(0001) at θN = 0. 5 ML is 4.1•105 times higher than at θN = 0.25 ML, due to an increase in QN+H by 1.2 eV (Tables 2 and 3). In contrast to Re(0001), both N atoms bind to the Re atom of the centers Re1 and Re2, forming the local coverage of θN = 2 ML and 1 ML, respectively (Fig. 3b). In addition to lateral interaction, binding N to Re and Co reduces QN of the states (A1) and (C1) on Re1, and (A2) and (C2) on Re2 as compared to (A) on Re(0001). As a result, the specific TOF of the centers Re1/Co(0001), Re2/Co(0001), and the plane Re(0001), provided by weakly bound N states, changes in the order 8.0·103, 32.0, and 1.0, respectively, at θN = 0.5 ML. The strongly bound N atoms exhibit a ∼0.15 Å longer ReN bond and much lower activity compared to the weakly bound N atoms (Table S8). According to calculations, the predecessors (a1), (b1) and (c1), after the active N atoms are consumed, react exothermically with the nearby N2 molecule, eventually forming optimized states similar to (A1), (B1) and (C1), and close the catalytic cycle (Table 4 ). The calculations revealed stable states ReNNRe, NNRe, and ReNNReCo, which have an activated N-N bond with an increased N-N distance of dNN = 1.237 Å, 1.135 Å, and 1.197 Å, respectively, compared to dNN = 1.107 Å in a free N2 molecule. These states convert under hydrogenation to states with the separated N and NH species discussed above. The experimental ratio of the specific TOFs of the Re ( 11 2 ¯ 1 ) and Re(0001) crystal faces is 2.8•103 (P = 20 atm, H2/N2 = 3, and T = 870 K) [11], while the ratio of the specific TOFs of the Re1/Co(0001) and Re(0001) planes calculated for experimental conditions is 3.7•103 (Table S1). Therefore, the single-atom Re catalyst is 1.3 times more active than the most active single crystal Re ( 11 2 ¯ 1 ) . However, this seems to be insufficient for practical use due to the complexity of manufacturing and probable instability of the Re1 and Re2 centers, which can aggregate into islands and thus change their thermodynamic properties. 3.2.3 DOS The almost full Re6p and Co3p orbitals were found for the configurations considered. The partial density of states (pDOS) of the free N states on Re(0001) do not correlate with QN and TOF in Fig. 1 and exhibit a single Re6s orbital. At θN = 0.5 ML, N states with equal and different N atoms show overlapping orbitals of Re6s and N2s, split by ∼1 eV and ∼2.5 eV, respectively (Fig. 4 ). A common feature of active N atoms is the overlap of N2s and Re6s, while N2p is shared between the Re5d and Co3d orbitals. In contrast, both the N2s and N2p orbitals of the inactive N atoms overlap mostly with the Co4s orbital. Generally, the active N atom has a lower negative charge and QN , as well as a higher QN+H than the inactive N atom (Tables 3, 5 , and Table S8). The Re atom of the Re1 and Re2 centers has a higher positive charge than the topmost Re atom of the Re(0001) plane, which does not affect the outer shell of N (Table 5). The conductivity of the support of the Re1 and Re2 centers is of little importance compared to the thermodynamics of the adsorbed layer. Thus, both one and a pair of Re atoms on Co(0001), in contrast to Re(0001), split N atoms in electronic and thermodynamic properties, forming highly active N states. 3.3 Co(0001), Co1/Re(0001), and Fe(111) The free N states on the Co(0001), Co1/Re(0001), and Fe(111) slabs (Fig. S1) are characterized in Fig. 5 and Table 6 . Cobalt is semi-active in the dissociative N2 adsorption and ammonia synthesis [3,31]. Nevertheless, the states N on Co(0001), if formed, exhibit significant catalytic activity. The calculated BE = -5.64 eV and Co-N distance ∼1.765 Å of the fcc state NCo3 are close to the reported data -5.56 eV and 1.769 Å, respectively [32]. Two stable N states on the slab Co1/Re(0001) were found. The fcc and hcp sites of the support Re(0001) are more preferable for the N states than the Co-based sites. Thus, the perturbation of the Re(0001) plane by the Co atom is negligible and leads in a specific TOF of the Co1/Re (0001) system close to Re(0001). Two optimized configurations were found on the Fe(111) plane. The Nad atom of the FeN and Fe3N state is localized at 1.54 Å and 0.20 Å above the uppermost Fe layer, respectively. The distance between the Fe atoms of the 1st and 3rd, as well as the 2nd and 3rd layers of the state Fe3N, decreases by 0.08 Å and increases by 0.11 Å, respectively, compared to the pure Fe(111) plane. The deep embedding of the N atom and the rearrangement of the surface are consistent with previous experimental and theoretical studies [64,73,74]. The calculated values of QN = 1.09 eV and QN+H = -0.53 eV of the Fe3N state are in agreement with the published theoretical and experimental data of 0.97-1.15 eV and -0.50 eV, respectively [64,65,69,75]. The experimental ratio of the rates of catalytic synthesis of NH3 (total P = 20 atm, N2/H2 = 1/3) on polycrystalline Re and Fe(111) single crystal is 7.5, 9.6, and 14.5 at T = 798 K, 713 K and 603 K, respectively [13,18]. This order is consistent with the specific TOF of the planes Re(0001) and Fe(111), equal to 9.0, 9.8, and 11.2, respectively, which were calculated for the same T, P and optimized atomic densities (Table S1). 3.4 Re-Co alloys Steps (1-3) on planes (0001) of the alloys ReδCo1-δ (δ = 0; 0.25; 0.5; 0.75; 1) were studied using the optimized lattice parameters in order to evaluate the atomic densities and the specific TOFs (Table 7 ). The weighted mean QN were calculated for free N states (Table 8 ) and for θN = 0.5 ML; the weighted mean QH for free and for the N -covered surfaces of the slabs (θN = 0.25 and 0.5 ML) were determined. The differences of 0.01 eV and 0.05 eV in QH and QN , respectively, found with the optimized and experimental lattice parameters of the slabs Co(0001) and Re(0001) did not affect the conclusions. The QH for free slabs ReδCo1-δ(0001) increases with δ approximately as a linear combination of the QH of alloy components (Table 1), whereas the dependences QH (δ) for N -covered surfaces are not linear (Fig. 6 (a)). A minimum of QH (δ) and a maximum of QN+H (δ) at θN = 0.5 ML are responsible for the maximal TOF of the corresponding Re1Co3 alloy under commercial conditions, in which step (3) is assumed to be the RDS (Fig. 6(b, d)). The calculated TOF ratio of the most active alloy Re1Co3/Re is ∼750. The QN(δ) increases with δ at θN = 0.5 ML, alike the case of H2 adsorption on free slabs, while exhibits a maximum at θN = 0.25 ML, despite the strong advantage of QN (Re) = 1.46 eV over QN (Co) = 0.35 eV (Table 8). The latter QN (δ) dependence provides a synergistic behavior of the alloy under mild conditions in agreement with the experimental data (Fig. 7 (a)) [44], assuming that step (2) is the RDS, and using the BEP coefficient β = 0.45 for close-packed surfaces [27] and optimized atomic densities (Table 7). The calculated TOF ratio of the most active alloy Re3Co1/Re is ∼30. The Re atoms of the NRe3 state on Re3Co1(0001) (with an abnormally high QN = 1.81 eV) differ in the Re-N distance and the 5d shell filling, in contrast to the Re atoms of the similar NRe3 state on Re(0001) (QN = 1.46 eV) (Table 8 and Fig. 7). The correlation between the QN and the M-N distance of dominant (in QN and TOF) configurations, as well as the electron transfer between the Re atoms in the alloy, seems obvious from Fig. 7(c), but no significant differences were found between their atomic charges and pDOS structures (Fig. 8 ). Thus, the synergy of Re-Co alloys in the synthesis of ammonia depends on the RDS. A Re- or Co-rich alloy exhibits maximum TOF if the RDS is Nad formation or hydrogenation, respectively. The variable synergy should be taken into account when developing alloy-based catalysts: the inversion of synergy can occur at the maximum of the TOF(QN ) dependence [35,36], where a change in the RDS is very likely. 4 Conclusions Re-based active sites for the catalytic synthesis of ammonia are investigated in this study using DFT calculations and kinetic modeling. It is shown that the Co(0001)-supported Re1 and Re2 centers split the Nad atoms in electronic and thermodynamic properties, providing a slightly higher activity than the most active single crystal Re ( 11 2 ¯ 1 ) . The metal-on-metal systems have little practical significance, but the catalytic performance of weakly bound N atoms on a surface modified by strongly bound N atoms should also manifest themselves in more realistic catalytic systems. The synergistic behavior of ReδCo1-δ alloys is established: the Re1Co3 alloy has the maximum TOF under commercial conditions, in which Nad hydrogenation is considered to be the rate-determining step. The NRe3 state on the Re3Co1 alloy has an abnormally high BE = -7.05 eV compared to BE = -6.71 eV of the similar NRe3 state on Re. As a result, the synergy changes, and the Re3Co1 alloy exhibits maximum TOF under mild conditions, in which the formation of Nad is probably the rate-determining step. When developing complex catalysts, the possibility of such a change in synergy should be taken into account. CRediT authorship contribution statement Alexander R. Cholach: Conceptualization, Investigation, Supervision, Validation, Writing – original draft. Anna A. Bryliakova: Investigation, Methodology, Writing – review & editing. coredata.dc:description: In this study, density functional theory calculations and microkinetic modeling were used to estimate the catalytic activity of ReδCo1-δ(0001) alloys (δ = 0; 0.25; 0.5; 0.75, 1), and Co(0001)-supported single- Re1 and dual-atom Re2 centers in the synthesis of ammonia. Nitrogen atoms (Nad) form an ordered structure, and the bridge state is most active among others on the Re(0001) plane; while Nad are concentrated around the Re1 and Re2 centers, splitting in electronic and thermodynamic properties. The specific catalytic activity of the centers Re1, Re2 and the Re(0001) plane changes in the order of 8.0·103, 32.0, and 1.0, respectively, due to weakly bound but highly active Nad, which are stabilized by strongly bound and low-active Nad. The calculations revealed the NRe3 state on the Re3Co1 alloy with an abnormally high binding energy (BE) of -7.05 eV, unequal Re-N distances and Re5d fillings, in contrast to the similar NRe3 state on Re(0001) with BE = -6.71 eV. A variable synergism of Re-Co alloys was established: the Re3Co1 or Re1Co3 alloy exhibits maximum catalytic activity if the rate-determining step is the formation or hydrogenation of Nad under appropriate experimental conditions, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: Re-Co alloys and single-atom Re catalysts in ammonia synthesis: A DFT study
